extractedContent:
Application Number: 242725
Filename: FISH RIVER RURAL HEALTH_Application-242725.pdf
Processed: 2026-01-23T04:25:47.838Z

compliantItems.element: Element b - Update of Needs Assessment
compliantItems.requirement: The health center completes or updates a needs assessment of the current or proposed population at least once every three years, for the purposes of informing and improving the delivery of health center services. The needs assessment utilizes the most recently available data for the service area and, if applicable, special populations and addresses the following:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center completes or updates a needs assessment of the current or proposed population at least once every three years, for the purposes of informing and improving the delivery of health center services. The needs assessment utilizes the most recently available data for the service area and, if applicable, special populations and addresses the following:
compliantItems.evidence:
1. The application narrative (see '5. Describe how you will: a. Conduct and update your needs assessment') states: 'FRRH conducts a triennial comprehensive assessment informed by several data sources. Analysis includes data from UDS, American Community Survey and Population Estimate Program data, RWJF County Health Rankings, Maine's Department of Health and Human Services CHNA, the Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance Survey (BRFSS), Maine CDC data, and data from local partners. Annually FRRH refreshes ZIP code and service mix to analyze to confirm where patients reside and the services that they need.'
2. The Needs Assessment section includes detailed data tables and narrative using the most recent available data (e.g., 2025 Maine Shared CHNA, 2024 UDS, 2022-2024 population estimates, etc.).
3. The application describes annual review processes and triennial comprehensive needs assessment, with explicit reference to informing service delivery and scope changes (e.g., expansion of dental services in response to MaineCare changes, new pharmacy services, etc.).
4. The application provides evidence of use of the needs assessment to inform and improve delivery of services (e.g., expansion of school-based health centers, transportation services, food shelf program, etc.).
5. The application includes a summary of changes since the last SAC application (2022), including population growth, changes in patient demographics, and service area needs, all supported by current data.
6. The application describes the use of multiple data sources, including UDS, Maine Shared CHNA, GeoCare Navigator, and local partner data.
compliantItems.reasoning: The application demonstrates that Fish River Rural Health (FRRH) completes a comprehensive needs assessment at least once every three years, as required. The narrative and data tables provide evidence of use of the most recent available data for the service area, including special populations (though FRRH does not receive HP, MSAW, or RPH funding, so those populations are not specifically addressed). The needs assessment is explicitly used to inform and improve service delivery, as evidenced by changes in scope and services described in the application. There is also evidence of annual review and update of service area data. Therefore, the application is COMPLIANT with Element b - Update of Needs Assessment.

compliantItems.element: Element b - Sliding Fee Discount Program Policies
compliantItems.requirement: The health center has board-approved policy(ies) for its sliding fee discount program that apply uniformly to all patients and address the following areas:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center has board-approved policy(ies) for its sliding fee discount program that apply uniformly to all patients and address the following areas:
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 13: Health Center Program Compliance states: 'As described in Attachment 10: Sliding Fee Discount Schedule, FRRH's Sliding Fee Discount Program (SFDP) applies, at a minimum, to FRRH's Column I services as outlined on Form 5A, and is compliant with the following elements: Uniform applicability to all patients... Eligibility for program participation is based solely on annual income and household/family size, as it relates to the most current Federal Poverty Guidelines (FPGs). No other factors for eligibility are taken into consideration. The program is consistently advertised and offered to all patients, insured and uninsured.' The policy is described as board-approved and is referenced in the application narrative and Attachment 13. The Board's annual review and approval of the sliding fee schedule and associated policies is also described. The policy is confirmed as applying uniformly to all patients and addresses income/family size, eligibility, nominal charges, and annual review. The Board-approved policy is referenced in Form 1C and Attachment 13.
compliantItems.reasoning: The application provides clear, direct evidence of a board-approved sliding fee discount program policy that applies uniformly to all patients, is reviewed annually, and addresses all required areas (income/family size, eligibility, nominal charges, annual review, uniform application, etc.). The policy is referenced multiple times, and the board's role is documented in the bylaws and compliance attachments.

compliantItems.element: Element c - Sliding Fee for Column I Services
compliantItems.requirement: For services provided directly by the health center (Form 5A: Services Provided, Column I), the health center's SFDS(s) is structured consistent with its policy and provides discounts as follows:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: For services provided directly by the health center (Form 5A: Services Provided, Column I), the health center's SFDS(s) is structured consistent with its policy and provides discounts as follows:
compliantItems.evidence: Form 5A shows that all required primary care, dental, behavioral health, optometry, nutrition, and enabling services are provided directly (Column I). Attachment 10: Sliding Fee Discount Schedule provides a detailed SFDS table, showing discount levels A-D for incomes up to 200% FPG, and Level E (full charge) above 200%. The fee schedule includes nominal charges for patients at or below 100% FPG ($10 for medical/preventive dental, $30 for restorative dental), and incremental charges for higher income bands. Attachment 13 confirms the SFDS is applied to all Column I services and is consistent with policy. The narrative and Attachment 13 further confirm that the SFDS is applied to all direct services, and the schedule is structured as required.
compliantItems.reasoning: The application provides the actual SFDS (Attachment 10), which is structured in accordance with policy and HRSA requirements, and applies to all direct (Column I) services as confirmed in the narrative and compliance attachments. The schedule provides for nominal charges, incremental discounts, and full charges as required, and is board-approved. There is no evidence of exclusion of any Column I service.

compliantItems.element: Element e - Incorporation of Current Federal Poverty Guidelines
compliantItems.requirement: The health center's SFDS(s) has incorporated the most recent FPG.
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center's SFDS(s) has incorporated the most recent FPG.
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 10: Sliding Fee Discount Schedule is labeled 'Effective September 1, 2025' and the income bands for each family size match the 2025 Federal Poverty Guidelines (FPG) as published by HHS. Attachment 13 explicitly states: 'The most recent FRRH Sliding Fee Discount Schedule (SFDS - see Attachment 10) for services provided directly (consistent with Form 5A) was updated to reflect the 2025 FPG.' The application narrative also references annual updates to the SFDS based on the most recent FPG.
compliantItems.reasoning: The SFDS provided uses the most recent FPG (2025), as required. The application narrative and compliance attachment confirm annual updates and board approval. The evidence is clear, direct, and meets the requirement.

compliantItems.element: Element b - Documentation of Key Management Staff Positions
compliantItems.requirement: The health center has documented the training and experience qualifications, as well as the duties or functions, for each key management staff position (for example, in position descriptions).
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center has documented the training and experience qualifications, as well as the duties or functions, for each key management staff position (for example, in position descriptions).
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 4: Position Descriptions for Key Management Staff provides detailed job descriptions for each key management staff position, including Executive Director/CEO, Medical Director, Director of Finance & HR, Director of Clinical Quality & Risk Management, Director of Technology, Director of Family Medicine & Behavioral Health Services, Director of Dental Services, Director of Optometry & Chiropractic Services, and Director of Pharmacy Services. Each description includes duties/responsibilities, qualifications/experience, supervisory relationships, and knowledge/skills. Attachment 5: Biographical Sketches for Key Management Staff provides resumes/CVs for individuals in these positions, documenting their training and experience. The narrative in the Capacity section references Attachments 3, 4, and 5 for documentation of qualifications and duties. Form 2 - Staffing Profile lists the key management positions as direct hires.
compliantItems.reasoning: The application provides comprehensive documentation of both the required qualifications and the duties/functions for each key management staff position through the referenced attachments and narrative. The information is specific, current, and covers all key positions, meeting the requirement for documented training, experience, and duties.

compliantItems.requirement: The health center's Project Director/CEO is directly employed by the health center, reports to the health center's governing board and is responsible for overseeing other key management staff in carrying out the day-to-day activities necessary to fulfill the HRSA-approved scope of project.
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center's Project Director/CEO is directly employed by the health center, reports to the health center's governing board and is responsible for overseeing other key management staff in carrying out the day-to-day activities necessary to fulfill the HRSA-approved scope of project.
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 4: Position Descriptions for Key Management Staff clearly states the Executive Director/CEO is 'Directly employed by FRRH,' reports to the Board of Directors, and oversees employees and contractors in day-to-day operations. The Bylaws (Attachment 2, Section 2.1c) specify the Board is responsible for hiring, evaluating, and dismissing the Executive Director/CEO. The Organizational Chart (Attachment 3) shows the CEO at the top, reporting to the Board, and overseeing all other key management staff. The Capacity section narrative confirms the CEO is directly employed, reports to the Board, and oversees the management team. Form 2 - Staffing Profile lists the CEO as a direct hire (1.00 FTE). The CEO's biographical sketch (Attachment 5) further confirms her employment status and role.
compliantItems.reasoning: The application provides clear, consistent, and multiple forms of evidence that the CEO is directly employed by the health center, reports to the governing board, and is responsible for overseeing other key management staff in daily operations. This fully meets the HRSA requirement.

compliantItems.element: Element e - HRSA Approval for Contracting Substantive Programmatic Work
compliantItems.requirement: If the health center has arrangements with a contractor to perform substantive programmatic work, the health center requested and received prior approval from HRSA as documented by:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: If the health center has arrangements with a contractor to perform substantive programmatic work, the health center requested and received prior approval from HRSA as documented by:
compliantItems.evidence: Form 8 - Health Center Agreements states: 'Do you currently have, or plan to utilize: a) Contract(s) with another organization to perform substantive programmatic work within the proposed scope of project?' Answer: No. Also, Attachment 13: Health Center Program Compliance states: 'FRRH is the sole recipient of the federal FQHC 330 grant award, and does not have subrecipients, as demonstrated on Attachment 7: Summary of Contracts and Agreements and Form 8: Health Center Agreements.'
compliantItems.reasoning: FRRH does not contract with another organization to perform substantive programmatic work (i.e., does not contract for a majority of required health services or providers). All required services are provided directly by FRRH staff except for a few specific services (e.g., labor & delivery, translation, 340B administration, labs) which are not considered 'substantive programmatic work' as defined by HRSA. Therefore, the requirement for HRSA prior approval is not triggered, and the organization is compliant.

compliantItems.requirement: The health center's contracts that support the HRSA-approved scope of project include provisions that address the following:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center's contracts that support the HRSA-approved scope of project include provisions that address the following:
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 7: Summary of Contracts and Agreements details each contract, including description of services, process for tracking patients for follow-up care, and contract timeframes. Attachment 13: Health Center Program Compliance states: 'All organizations that provide contracted services to FRRH patients enter into a signed contract that outlines their responsibilities as a FRRH business partner... All contracts include a detailed scope of work, which guides the CEO's ongoing review to ensure the contractor is providing all services as agreed to. Invoices are received with the appropriate scope of work attached. Once a contract is completed, documentation including reports, invoices, and scope of work, is retained for three years after the date of the submission of the final financial report as required by federal regulations. Where applicable, contracts also include provisions for property management to ensure compliance with federal standards. Finally, each contract includes provisions that allow FRRH access to contractor records and reports related to all health center activities to ensure they are being carried out in accordance with provisions and timelines specified in the contract and in compliance with the Health Center Program Compliance Manual and Health Center Program Site Visit Protocol.'
compliantItems.reasoning: Contracts for services (e.g., Cary Medical Center for labor & delivery, WellPartner for 340B, Propio for translation, Quest Diagnostics for labs, etc.) are described in Attachment 7 and include required provisions for scope of work, monitoring, reporting, record retention, audit, and property management. Attachment 13 confirms that contracts are developed per federal procurement standards and include all required provisions. Therefore, the organization is compliant.

notApplicableItems.element: Element g - HRSA Approval to Subaward (Not Applicable for Look-alikes)
notApplicableItems.requirement: If the health center has made a subaward, the health center requested and received prior approval from HRSA as documented by:
notApplicableItems.whatWasChecked: If the health center has made a subaward, the health center requested and received prior approval from HRSA as documented by:
notApplicableItems.evidence: Form 8 - Health Center Agreements: 'Do you currently have, or plan to utilize: ... b) Subawards to carry out a portion of the proposed scope of project.' Answer: 0. Attachment 13: 'FRRH is the sole recipient of the federal FQHC 330 grant award, and does not have subrecipients, as demonstrated on Attachment 7: Summary of Contracts and Agreements and Form 8: Health Center Agreements.'
notApplicableItems.reasoning: FRRH does not have any subawards or subrecipients. The requirement is not applicable because there are no subawards.

notApplicableItems.element: Element h - Subaward Agreement (Not Applicable for Look-alikes)
notApplicableItems.requirement: The health center's subaward(s) that supports the HRSA-approved scope of project includes provisions that address the following:
notApplicableItems.whatWasChecked: The health center's subaward(s) that supports the HRSA-approved scope of project includes provisions that address the following:
notApplicableItems.evidence: Form 8 - Health Center Agreements: 'Do you currently have, or plan to utilize: ... b) Subawards to carry out a portion of the proposed scope of project.' Answer: 0. Attachment 13: 'FRRH is the sole recipient of the federal FQHC 330 grant award, and does not have subrecipients, as demonstrated on Attachment 7: Summary of Contracts and Agreements and Form 8: Health Center Agreements.'
notApplicableItems.reasoning: FRRH does not have any subawards or subrecipients. The requirement is not applicable because there are no subawards.

compliantItems.element: Element a - Coordination and Integration of Activities
compliantItems.requirement: The health center documents its efforts to collaborate with other providers or programs in the service area, including local hospitals, specialty providers, and social service organizations (including those that serve special populations), to provide access to services not available through the health center in order to support:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center documents its efforts to collaborate with other providers or programs in the service area, including local hospitals, specialty providers, and social service organizations (including those that serve special populations), to provide access to services not available through the health center in order to support:
compliantItems.evidence: The application provides extensive documentation of collaborative relationships with local hospitals (Cary Medical Center, Northern Maine Medical Center), specialty providers (Pines Health Services for OB/GYN, Aroostook Mental Health Center), and social service organizations (Aroostook County Action Program, Aroostook Agency on Aging, Good Shepherd Food Bank, Valley Unified Education Service Center, etc.). Table 36 in the narrative lists organizations with which FRRH has MOAs, letters of support, or grant funding relationships. Attachment 7: Summary of Contracts and Agreements details formal agreements for services not available directly through FRRH (e.g., labor & delivery, diagnostic radiology, translation, transportation, etc.). Letters of support from these partners are included in Attachment 9. The narrative describes how these collaborations provide access to services not available through the health center, such as labor & delivery, specialty women's health, emergency transport, and housing assistance.
compliantItems.reasoning: FRRH has provided clear, specific, and current evidence of active collaboration with a wide range of local hospitals, specialty providers, and social service organizations. These relationships are formalized through MOAs and contracts, and are supported by letters of support. The documentation demonstrates that FRRH coordinates and integrates activities to ensure access to services not available directly through the health center, fully meeting the requirement.

compliantItems.element: Element b - Collaboration with Other Primary Care Providers
compliantItems.requirement: The health center documents its efforts to coordinate and integrate its activities with other federally-funded, as well as State and local, health services delivery projects and programs serving similar patient populations in the service area (at a minimum, this would include establishing and maintaining relationships with other health centers in the service area).
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center documents its efforts to coordinate and integrate its activities with other federally-funded, as well as State and local, health services delivery projects and programs serving similar patient populations in the service area (at a minimum, this would include establishing and maintaining relationships with other health centers in the service area).
compliantItems.evidence: The application describes strong, ongoing collaboration with other HRSA-supported health centers in the service area, specifically Pines Health Services and Katahdin Valley Health Center. The narrative details joint projects (e.g., school-based health center in Van Buren with Pines, EHR/UDS+ learning with KVHC), mutual letters of support (Attachment 9), and respectful, long-standing relationships. The application also documents participation in the Maine Primary Care Association (state PCA), MaineCHCNet (HCCN), and Community Care Partnership of Maine (ACO), which are statewide networks for FQHCs and primary care. FRRH participates in state and local health initiatives, such as the Maine Shared Community Health Needs Assessment, and collaborates with local public health agencies and school districts. Attachment 9 and Table 36 further support these relationships.
compliantItems.reasoning: FRRH has provided clear documentation of its efforts to coordinate and integrate activities with other federally-funded, state, and local health services delivery projects and programs. The relationships with other FQHCs are well-established, current, and supported by formal documentation. FRRH also participates in statewide and regional networks, further supporting compliance with this element.

compliantItems.element: Element c - Participation in Insurance Programs
compliantItems.requirement: The health center participates in Medicaid, CHIP, Medicare, and, as appropriate, other public or private assistance programs or health insurance.
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center participates in Medicaid, CHIP, Medicare, and, as appropriate, other public or private assistance programs or health insurance.
compliantItems.evidence: Form 3: Income Analysis shows revenue from Medicaid ($4,972,139.60), Medicare ($984,144.00), and Private Insurance ($4,922,532.20). The narrative in Attachment 13: Health Center Program Compliance states: 'FRRH's Patient Service Revenue includes a strong mix of Medicaid, Medicare, Private insurance and self-pay income. Medicaid income includes Maine's version of CHIP via MaineCare.' Additionally, the application narrative describes eligibility assistance for Medicaid/MaineCare, Medicare, and Maine's Health Insurance Marketplace (CoverME.gov).
compliantItems.reasoning: The application provides clear and direct evidence that Fish River Rural Health (FRRH) participates in Medicaid, CHIP (via MaineCare), Medicare, and private insurance programs. This is substantiated by both the income analysis and narrative descriptions of insurance enrollment assistance and billing practices. There is no indication of exclusion from any required insurance program, and the center actively assists patients in enrolling in these programs.

compliantItems.element: Element h - Policies or Procedures for Waiving or Reducing Fees
compliantItems.requirement: The health center has and utilizes board-approved policies, as well as operating procedures, that include the specific circumstances when the health center will waive or reduce fees or payments required by the center due to any patient's inability to pay.
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center has and utilizes board-approved policies, as well as operating procedures, that include the specific circumstances when the health center will waive or reduce fees or payments required by the center due to any patient's inability to pay.
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 13: Health Center Program Compliance describes a Board-approved Sliding Fee Discount Program (SFDP) and a Billing and Collections Policy #21 that includes a Waiver of Fees policy statement. The narrative states: 'If a patient identifies with an inability to pay despite the resources FRRH has provided them, they will be referred to the Practice Site Manager. The Practice Site Manager will request that the patient submit a letter of financial hardship describing extenuating circumstances to the CEO for consideration of waiver or reduction.' Specific examples of financial hardship are listed (e.g., terminal illness, death/disability of family member, sudden unemployment, loss of home due to disaster, etc.). The process for review and notification is described, and the policy is Board-approved. The Sliding Fee Discount Schedule (Attachment 10) and related narrative further support this.
compliantItems.reasoning: The application provides detailed, board-approved policies and procedures for waiving or reducing fees, including a clear process for patients to request a waiver, specific examples of qualifying circumstances, and a defined review process. The existence of these policies, their board approval, and their operationalization are all documented in the application and attachments. This meets the HRSA requirement.

compliantItems.element: Element a - Budgeting for Scope of Project
compliantItems.requirement: The health center develops and submits to HRSA (for new or continued funding or designation from HRSA) an annual budget, also referred to as a 'total budget,' that reflects projected costs and revenues necessary to support the health center's proposed or HRSA-approved scope of project.
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center develops and submits to HRSA (for new or continued funding or designation from HRSA) an annual budget, also referred to as a 'total budget,' that reflects projected costs and revenues necessary to support the health center's proposed or HRSA-approved scope of project.
compliantItems.evidence: The application includes a full SF-424A Budget Information form, a detailed Budget Narrative, and a Personnel Justification Table. The budget totals $18,362,420 and is broken down by object class category (personnel, fringe, travel, supplies, contractual, other), with federal and non-federal sources clearly delineated. The narrative describes how the budget supports the scope of project, including projected patient growth, service expansion, and alignment with the work plan. The budget is consistent across all documents (see SF-424A, Budget Narrative, and Personnel Justification Table).
compliantItems.reasoning: The application provides a comprehensive annual budget that includes all projected costs and revenues necessary to support the health centerâ€™s HRSA-approved scope of project. The budget is consistent, detailed, and aligns with the proposed work plan and patient projections, meeting the requirement.

compliantItems.requirement: In addition to the Health Center Program award, the health center's annual budget includes all other projected revenue sources that will support the Health Center Program project, specifically:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: In addition to the Health Center Program award, the health center's annual budget includes all other projected revenue sources that will support the Health Center Program project, specifically:
compliantItems.evidence: The SF-424A and Budget Narrative detail all revenue sources: Federal (HRSA award: $2,234,067), Program Income ($11,711,316), State Funds ($146,555), Applicant Organization ($72,000), and Other Income (340B Pharmacy Contract, ACO Shared Savings: $4,198,482). Form 3 - Income Analysis further breaks down patient service revenue by payer (Medicaid, Medicare, Private, Self-Pay), and other sources (federal, state, local, other). The total revenue matches across all forms and narratives.
compliantItems.reasoning: The application clearly identifies all revenue sources that will support the Health Center Program project, including federal, state, program income, and other sources, as required. The information is consistent and comprehensive.

compliantItems.element: Element a - Maintenance of Board Authority Over Health Center Project
compliantItems.requirement: The health center's organizational structure, articles of incorporation, bylaws, and other relevant documents ensure the health center governing board maintains the authority for oversight of the Health Center Program project, specifically:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center's organizational structure, articles of incorporation, bylaws, and other relevant documents ensure the health center governing board maintains the authority for oversight of the Health Center Program project, specifically:
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 2: Bylaws, Section 2.1 (General Powers and Board Responsibilities) states 'All the corporate powers shall be and are hereby vested in and shall be exercised by the Board of Directors.' Section 2.10 (Directors - Residuary Powers) states 'The Board shall have the powers and duties necessary or appropriate for the administration of the affairs of the corporation. All powers of the corporation shall be vested in the Board.' Section 4.1 (Executive Director Responsibilities) clarifies that the Executive Director is accountable to the Board and that the Board may designate specific contracts or thresholds for Board approval. Attachment 13: Health Center Program Compliance, Governance: Board Authority, reiterates these points and confirms no other entity or committee reserves approval authority or has veto power over the board regarding required authorities and functions. Form 8 - Health Center Agreements confirms there is no parent, affiliate, or subsidiary organization, and no contracts for substantive programmatic work.
compliantItems.reasoning: The bylaws and compliance documentation clearly establish that the Board holds all corporate powers and ultimate authority over the health center project. The Board's authority is not delegated to any other entity or committee, and the Executive Director operates under Board oversight. There are no arrangements or contracts that would infringe upon Board authority. This meets HRSA requirements for maintenance of Board authority.

compliantItems.element: Element b - Required Authorities and Responsibilities
compliantItems.requirement: The health center's articles of incorporation, bylaws, or other relevant documents outline the following required authorities and responsibilities of the governing board:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center's articles of incorporation, bylaws, or other relevant documents outline the following required authorities and responsibilities of the governing board:
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 2: Bylaws, Section 2.1 (General Powers and Board Responsibilities) and Attachment 13: Health Center Program Compliance, Governance: Board Authority, list the following required authorities: (1) Hiring, annually evaluating, and dismissing the Executive Director/CEO (2.1c, 2.1d); (2) Approving the annual project budget and applications (2.1e); (3) Approving proposed health center services, locations, and hours of operation (2.1h); (4) Evaluating the performance of the health center (2.1i); (5) Establishing/adopting policies related to operations (2.1d, 2.1h); (6) Ensuring compliance with applicable laws and regulations (2.1g); (7) Accepting the annual audit report (2.1k); (8) Approving the annual project plan (2.1l); (9) Board size and composition requirements (2.2); (10) Conflict of interest provisions (2.11); (11) No other entity or committee has veto power over the board (2.10). These are explicitly referenced in Attachment 13, which crosswalks each required authority to the relevant bylaw section.
compliantItems.reasoning: The bylaws and compliance narrative directly address and enumerate all required board authorities and responsibilities as specified by HRSA. The board's role in selection/dismissal of the CEO, budget and application approval, service and site oversight, policy adoption, compliance, audit acceptance, and self-evaluation are all clearly documented. Board composition and conflict of interest requirements are also met. There is no evidence of any restriction on these authorities. Therefore, this element is compliant.

compliantItems.element: Element a - Board Member Selection and Removal Process
compliantItems.requirement: The health center has bylaws or other relevant documents that specify the process for ongoing selection and removal of board members. This board member selection and removal process does not permit any other entity, committee or individual (other than the board) to select either the board chair or the majority of health center board members, including a majority of the non-patient board members.
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center has bylaws or other relevant documents that specify the process for ongoing selection and removal of board members. This board member selection and removal process does not permit any other entity, committee or individual (other than the board) to select either the board chair or the majority of health center board members, including a majority of the non-patient board members.
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 2: Bylaws, Section 2.8 states, 'The Board of Directors shall fill any vacancy occurring in the Board. A director elected by the directors to fill a vacancy shall be elected for the unexpired term of his/her predecessor in office.' Section 3.2.1 states, 'The officers of the corporation specified in Section 3.1 shall be elected from the membership of the Board by the Board at its annual meeting or as soon thereafter as feasible.' Section 3.3 states, 'The Board may remove any officer or member elected or appointed by the Board by two-thirds vote of the remaining directors whenever in its judgment the best interest of the corporation would be served thereby.' There is no indication in the bylaws or application that any other entity, committee, or individual outside the board has authority to select the board chair or a majority of board members.
compliantItems.reasoning: The bylaws clearly assign all authority for selection and removal of board members and officers to the board itself, with no outside entity, committee, or individual having this authority. The process is described in detail and aligns with HRSA requirements.

compliantItems.requirement: The health center has bylaws or other relevant documents that require the board to be composed as follows:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center has bylaws or other relevant documents that require the board to be composed as follows:
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 2: Bylaws, Section 2.2 states, 'The number of directors shall not be less than nine or more than fifteen.' Section 2.1 states, 'Fifty-one percent (51%) of the directors shall be users and as geographically represented, of the service area, as possible.' Section 2.1 also requires that 'Patient members of the board, as a group, shall reasonably represent the individuals who are served by the health center in terms of demographic factors, such as race, ethnicity and sex.' Non-patient members must be representative of the community and selected for relevant expertise, and no more than half of non-consumer board members may derive more than 10% of their income from the health care industry. Section 2.11 prohibits employees and immediate family members from serving on the board.
compliantItems.reasoning: The bylaws explicitly include all HRSA-required board composition elements, including size, patient majority, demographic representation, non-patient expertise, income limits, and conflict of interest prohibitions.

compliantItems.requirement: The health center has documentation that the board is composed of:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center has documentation that the board is composed of:
compliantItems.evidence: Form 6A - Current Board Member Characteristics lists 12 board members, with 11 of 12 (92%) identified as health center patients, and all but one living or working in the service area. Areas of expertise include business, government, education, banking, management, and law. None derive more than 10% of income from the health industry. Application narrative confirms, 'FRRH consistently meets the 51% patient consumer board membership, often achieves 100%, and is currently at 92% with 11 of 12 board members who are patients.'
compliantItems.reasoning: The current board composition meets and exceeds HRSA requirements for patient majority, demographic and expertise representation, and conflict of interest. The documentation is clear and complete.

notApplicableItems.requirement: In cases where a health center receives an award/designation under section 330(g), 330(h) and/or 330(i), does not receive an award/designation under section 330(e), and requests a waiver of the patient majority board composition requirements, the health center presents to HRSA for review and approval:
notApplicableItems.whatWasChecked: In cases where a health center receives an award/designation under section 330(g), 330(h) and/or 330(i), does not receive an award/designation under section 330(e), and requests a waiver of the patient majority board composition requirements, the health center presents to HRSA for review and approval:
notApplicableItems.evidence: Form 6B - Request for Waiver of Board Member Requirements states: 'This form is not applicable to you, since you are currently receiving or applying to receive Community Health Center (CHC) funding and/or you have selected 'Tribal' or 'Urban Indian' as the Business Entity in Form 1A.' The application requests only 330(e) funding (see Summary Page and SF-424).
notApplicableItems.reasoning: FRRH is applying for/receiving only Community Health Center (CHC, 330(e)) funding and does not request a waiver of the patient majority board composition requirement. Therefore, this element is not applicable.
